description.narrative:
Kazakhstan was the first country in the Asia Pacific region to be directly affected by the global economic crisis. After a decade of rapid expansion at 9% real gross domestic product (GDP) growth per year, the economy plummeted in the second half of 2008, limiting growth to 3.3% that year. During January-June 2009, the economy is estimated to have contracted by 2.3% year-on-year, and the full-year decline in 2009 is projected at 2%, according to the International Monetary Fund forecast. The financial sector was the worst affected, as banks were overexposed to external financing sources that dried up in August 2007 as the international liquidity crisis struck. Global creditors tightened liquidity, and Kazakh debt spreads widened sharply. Asset quality in the banking sector declined. The construction, industry, and trade sectors took major hits, with the impact of the crisis percolating down through the entire economy. There have been major job losses in some of these sectors. The impact of the crisis has also had ripple effects on the neighboring economies of the Kyrgyz Republic and the Republic of Tajikistan, which are dependent on Kazakhstan for investments as well as worker remittances.
The Government's policy response and actions have been swift. Kazakhstan's ability to weather the crisis has been due in large part to a considerable chest of oil earnings built up in the National Fund of the Republic of Kazakhstan (NFRK), helped by the increase in oil prices until 2008. NFRK grew from $14 billion in 2006 to $28 billion in 2008. In 2007-2008, the Government set aside $4 billion equivalent in its budget to finance the ambitious ACP, formulated in late 2007 jointly with the National Bank of Kazakhstan (NBK), the Financial Monitoring Supervisory Agency (FMSA), and other institutions. In November 2008, the Government expanded its crisis-mitigation measures with an additional $10 billion allocation out of NFRK. The ACP supports (i) banking sector rehabilitation, (ii) revival of the construction industry, (iii) greater role for small and medium-sized enterprises, (iv) revival of the agro-industrial sector, and (v) greater public investment in industry and infrastructure. It took a 75% stake in Bank Turan Alem, the country's largest bank with 27% of the system's assets. It also injected capital into Halyk Bank and Kazkommertzbank. In total, the Government has put into the banking system equity capital or deposits amounting to $5 billion. Reacting to competitive pressures, Kazakhstan devalued the national currency, the tenge, by 20% in February 2009. An employment-generation program (Roadmap for Recovery Through Job Creation) was launched in March 2009. In total, the Government's anti-crisis package has mobilized $22.5 billion of direct and indirect measures, and is beginning to show results.

title.narrative: Reports and Recommendations of the President
Reports and Recommendations of the President
Output indicators are in the Validation Report: https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/evaluation-document/36041/files/pvr-201.pdf
